questions.text: The complications associated with extubation are all except:

choices.text: Increased blood pressure and heart rate

questions.solution:
The complication associated with extubation is negative pressure pulmonary edema which is a dangerous and potentially fatal condition.

Complications associated with extubation:

  • Laryngospasm and bronchospasm
  • Negative pressure pulmonary edema
  • Upper airway obstruction
  • Hypoventilation
  • Hemodynamic changes (hypertension, tachycardia)
  • Coughing and straining leading to surgical wound dehiscence
  • Laryngeal or airway edema
  • Paradoxical vocal cord motion
  • Arytenoid dislocation
  • Aspiration

Factors associated with increased extubation risk:

  • Airway risk factors
    • known difficult airway
    • airway deterioration (bleeding, edema, trauma)
    • restricted airway access
    • obesity and obstructive sleep apnea
    • aspiration risk
  • General risk factors
    • cardiovascular disease
    • respiratory disease
    • neuromuscular disease
    • metabolic derangements
    • special surgical requirements

questions.text: What is the oxygen delivery rate of the device shown below?
questions.solution:
The equipment shown in the image is a non-rebreather mask. It can give up to 10-15 liters of oxygen per minute.

The non-rebreather mask is a low-flow device that can be used to deliver oxygen at higher concentrations (FiO2 80-95%). It is used in patients who are severely hypoxic but are ventilating well. It uses a reservoir bag to let the oxygen get concentrated while a one-way valve doesn't allow it to breathe in expired air.

Other examples of low-flow devices are:

  • Nasal cannula
  • Face mask
  • Face tent
  • Non-rebreather mask.

High-flow devices include:

  • Venturi mask
  • High flow nasal cannula
  • Mechanical ventilation

questions.text: A patient in hemorrhagic shock was shifted for emergency surgery and given ketamine for induction. Why is this drug preferred for use in this situation?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is preferred due to its indirect sympathomimetic action. It is the intravenous anesthetic of choice for hemorrhagic shock.

It inhibits the reuptake of both central and peripheral catecholamines and causes increased blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output.

Ketamine has direct negative inotropic and vasodilating activity, but these effects are overwhelmed by the indirect sympathomimetic action.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of perioperative vision loss?
questions.solution:
Ischemic optic neuropathy is the most common cause of perioperative vision loss.

It is usually seen after spine surgeries in the prone position, radical neck dissections and following cardiopulmonary bypass.

Symptoms: Reduced visual acuity, rarely complete blindness; usually presents on awakening from anesthesia.

Preoperative risk factors: 

  • Diabetes, hypertension
  • Smoking
  • Coronary artery disease.

Intraoperative risk factors: 

  • Anaemia
  • Hypotension
  • Prone position
  • Prolonged duration of surgery

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was scheduled for strabismus correction surgery. The induction of anesthesia was uneventful. After conjunctival incision as the surgeon grasps the medial rectus the anesthetist looks at the cardiac monitor. Why do you think he did that?

choices.text: To check the depth of anesthesia
To see if there was an oculocardiac reflex
To ensure there were no ventricular arrhythmias

questions.solution:
The anaesthetist would have looked at the monitor as soon as the medial rectus was grasped, to see if there was an oculocardiac reflex.

The oculocardiac reflex is a trigemino-vagal-reflex (afferent through trigeminal nerve, efferent through vagus nerve). It is most common in pediatric patients undergoing strabismus surgery. It is caused by traction on extraocular muscles or pressure on the eyeball and surrounding structures, particularly the medial rectus muscle.

Mechanism of reflex: Stretch receptors are located in the extraocular muscles. Once activated, the receptors send afferents through short and long ciliary nerves. The ciliary nerves will merge with the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve at the ciliary ganglion. The trigeminal nerve carries impulses to the Gasserian ganglion resulting in increased parasympathetic tone and bradycardia.

The manifestation can range from bradycardia (most common) to sinus arrest and ventricular ectopic to ventricular fibrillation. Administration of antimuscarinic drug glycopyrrolate or atropine reduces the incidence of bradycardia during eye surgery.

Treatment is done by temporary cessation of any surgical manipulation, prevention of hypercapnia or hypoxemia with adequate ventilation, IV glycopyrrolate or IV atropine if bradycardia persists. 

Related Pearl: Oculocardiac Reflex

Traction on the extraocular muscles or pressure on the globe causes bradycardia, atrioventricular block, ventricular ectopy, or asystole.

In particular, it is seen with traction on the medial rectus muscle, but it can occur with stimulation of any of the orbital contents, including the periosteum.

Reflex arc involves-

  • Afferent: Orbital contents to ciliary ganglion to ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve to the sensory nucleus of trigeminal
  • Efferent: Vagus nerve to the heart.

Procedures evoking the reflex-

  • Strabismus surgery in the paediatric age (most common) 
  • Cataract extraction
  • Enucleation
  • Retinal detachment repair.

Management-

  • Temporary cessation of surgical stimulation until heart rate increases
  • Adequate ventilation, oxygenation, and depth of anaesthesia
  • IV atropine (10 mcg/kg) if bradycardia persists
  • In recalcitrant episodes, local anaesthetic infiltration of the rectus muscles.

Pretreatment with intravenous atropine or glycopyrrolate can be effective in preventing this condition.

questions.text: A 5-month-old child is set to undergo a herniotomy procedure for congenital inguinal hernia under caudal anesthesia. Where is the local anesthetic injected into for this procedure?
questions.solution:
During caudal anaesthesia, the local anaesthetic is injected into the sacral portion of the epidural space.

Caudal anaesthesia involves a needle and/or catheter penetration of the sacrococcygeal ligament which opens into the caudal epidural space. The sacrococcygeal ligament covers the sacral hiatus that is created by the unfused S4 and S5 laminae.

Sacral hiatus is well appreciated in children. Hence, it is a common regional technique in paediatrics for procedures below the diaphragm, including urogenital, rectal, inguinal, and lower extremity surgery. 

It may also be used for anorectal surgery in adults but it is technically challenging in adults.

questions.text:
Following a road traffic accident, an unresponsive young man was brought to the emergency room. In order to declare him as brain dead, which of the following criteria can be used?

1. Absent spinal cord reflex

2. Isoelectric electroencephalogram (EEG)

3. Absent brain stem reflex

4. Decorticate posturing

5. Positive apnea test
questions.solution:
Absent spinal cord reflex and decorticate posturing are not criteria for brain death. The statements 2, 3 and 5 are correct.

Brain death is defined as the irreversible cessation of all brain function. Spinal cord function below C1 may still be present.

Brain death criteria can be applied only in the absence of:

  • Hypothermia 
  • Hypotension
  • Uncorrected metabolic or endocrine abnormalities
  • Neuromuscular blockers
  • Drugs known to depress brain function.

Generally accepted clinical criteria for brain death include the following:

  • Coma
  • Absent motor activity, including no decerebrate or decorticate posturing
  • Spinal cord reflexes may be preserved 
  • Absent brainstem reflexes, including no pupillary, corneal, vestibulocochlear (caloric), or gag (or cough) reflexes
  • Absence of ventilatory effort, with the arterial CO2 tension >60 mm Hg or 20 mm Hg above the pretest level (positive apnea test)

Confirmatory test findings (not mandatory but may assist in diagnosis)

  • Isoelectric electroencephalogram
  • Absence of brainstem auditory evoked potentials
  • Absence of cerebral perfusion as documented by angiographic, transcranial Doppler, or radioisotopic studies

questions.text: A middle aged man presents with complaints of shortness of breath, chest pain and cough. The following catheter is being used to evaluate the patient for pulmonary hypertension. Identify the catheter.
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the Swan-Ganz catheter used for pulmonary artery catheterization. It is also called the pulmonary artery catheter and is used to diagnose and evaluate pulmonary artery hypertension.

The standard pulmonary artery catheter is 110 cm long with a 7.0 – 9.0 Fr circumference. It contains 4 internal lumens. The distal port is used to measure PAP (pulmonary artery pressure) while the 2nd port is used to measure CVP (central venous pressure).

Pulmonary artery catheterization is a diagnostic procedure in which a catheter is passed through the central vein, into the right atrium and the right ventricle, and then is finally placed in the pulmonary artery.

The indications include:

  • Evaluation of pulmonary artery hypertension
  • Measurement of pressures in the right atrium, right ventricle, and pulmonary artery
  • Assessment of etiology and volume status in shock
  • Assessment of congenital heart disease, cardiac shunts, and right-sided valvular disease

Complications :

  • Catheterization related:
    1. Arrhythmias, ventricular fibrillation
    2. Right bundle branch block, complete heart block
  • Catheter residence related:
    1. Mechanical, catheter knots
    2. Thromboembolism
    3. Pulmonary infarction
    4. Infection, endocarditis
    5. Endocardial damage, cardiac valve injury
    6. Pulmonary artery rupture
    7. Pulmonary artery pseudoaneurysm
  • Others:
    1. Misinterpretation of data
    2. Misuse of equipment

Other options:

All the other catheters mentioned are used for establishing a central venous line for long-term total parenteral nutrition, medications, etc.

The given image shows a peripherally inserted central catheter (Option C). It can be inserted via peripheral veins in pediatric patients.

questions.text:
An intern in the anesthesia department was asked about the use of absorbents like soda lime in breathing systems. Which of the following statements are true regarding soda lime?
  1. Soda lime is less commonly used than barium hydroxide lime.
  2. The end products of the reaction of soda lime and CO2 are Na2CO3 + Ca(OH)2.
  3. The major constituent of soda lime is Ca(OH)2.
  4. Water content of soda lime is 5%.
  5. KOH is one of the components of soda lime.
questions.solution:
The statements that are true regarding soda lime are 3 and 5.

Soda lime is a CO2 absorbent used in the circle system (breathing system). It can absorb up to 23 L of CO2 per 100 g of absorbent. Its major constituent is Ca(OH)2 (80%). Other components include KOH, NaOH, and water (15%). It is also known as slaked lime.

A circle system is used in place of Mapleson circuits to avoid problems like loss of patient heat and humidity, waste of anesthetic agent due to high fresh gas flow, and pollution of the operating room environment. Components of this system are:

  1. CO2 absorber containing CO2 absorbent
  2. Fresh gas inlet
  3. Inspiratory unidirectional valve and inspiratory breathing tube
  4. Y-connector
  5. Expiratory unidirectional valve and expiratory breathing tube
  6. Adjustable pressure-limiting valve
  7. Reservoir

The reactions of soda lime granules with CO2 are as follows:

Step 1: CO2 + H2O (present on and within granules) → H2CO3

Step 2: 

  • H2CO3 + 2NaOH → Na2CO3 + 2H2O + Heat
  • H2CO3 + 2KOH → K2CO3 + 2H2O + Heat

All available strong bases are depleted.

Step 3:

  • Na2CO3 + Ca(OH)2 → CaCO3 (insoluble) + 2NaOH + Heat
  • K2CO3 + Ca(OH)2 → CaCO3 (insoluble) + 2KOH + Heat

NaOH and KOH are regenerated in this step, thereby acting as catalysts. This is the rate-limiting step since the NaOH and KOH regenerated in this step are required for step 2 for additional CO2 to be dissolved in water (step 1). Byproducts of this entire reaction are water and heat.

A pH indicator dye changes color from white to purple due to increasing H+ concentration and absorbent depletion. The absorbent should be replaced when 50-70% has changed color.

Absorbent granules can absorb and later release volatile anesthetics. This property is enhanced by the increased dryness of soda lime. Volatile anesthetics can be broken down to CO, resulting in clinically significant CO poisoning. Another absorbent, barium hydroxide lime, is no longer used due to the risk of fire in the system.

Related Pearl: Composition of CO2 Absorbers in rebreathing system

SODA LIME:

  • Ca(OH)2 - 80%
  • NaOH - 3%
  • KOH - 2%
  • Silica - 0.2%
  • Moisture-  14-19%

Granule size is 4-8 mesh

Absorbs up to 23L of CO2/100 g

With Trilene, soda-lime forms neurotoxin dichloroacetylene and pulmonary irritant phosgene gas; hence contraindicated.

Sevoflurane reacts with soda lime and produces Compound A

Method of hardness- Silica

AMSORB:

  • Ca(OH)2
  • Ca Cl2
  • CaSO4

Causes less degradation of volatile anesthetics eg. Sevoflurane to Compound A or Desflurane to Carbon Monoxide

BARALYME:

  • Ca(OH)2 80%
  • Ba(OH)2 20%
  • KOH <1%

Absorbs up to 9-18L of CO2/100 g

Desflurane can be broken down to CO by dry barium hydroxide lime.

Method of hardness: water of crystallization.

questions.text: During a routine evaluation of the operating room before an operation, you hear an alarm from the anesthesia workstation. Assuming it to be due to a leak from the oxygen cylinder, you immediately check the pressure gauge. What would be the maximum pressure that is normally expected in this medical gas cylinder?
questions.solution:
Maximum pressure in oxygen cylinder is 2000 psig (pounds per square inch gauge)

Maximum pressure in the E-cylinders:

  • 750 psig for nitrous oxide (liquid)
  • 2000 psig for air (gaseous)
  • 2000 psig for oxygen (gaseous)

Each cylinder is passed through a high-pressure regulator, which reduces the high pressures inside the cylinder to a lower, nearly constant pressure of 45 psig, which is suitable for use in the anesthesia machine.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of medical gas cylinders

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was being prepared for an emergency laparotomy and an endotracheal tube was inserted. Following intubation, end-tidal carbon dioxide was detected. However, his oxygen saturation dropped to 60% and breath sounds were not audible over the left hemithorax. What could be the cause of this?

choices.text: Endobronchial intubation into left main bronchus
Endobronchial intubation into right main bronchus

questions.solution:
Detection of end-tidal CO2 but dropping oxygen saturation with absent breath sounds over the left hemithorax points to endobronchial intubation into the right main bronchus.

Signs of endobronchial intubation:

  • Elevated peak inspiratory pressure (first sign)
  • Asymmetric chest expansion
  • Unilateral breath sounds
  • Drop in oxygen saturation

Capnography and detection of end-tidal CO2, though the surest confirmation for an advanced airway placement, does not differentiate endotracheal from endobronchial intubation.

Esophageal intubation: initial end-tidal CO2 may be detected due to swallowed air but later becomes zero. There would be the absence of breath sounds bilaterally with the presence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

questions.text: Which of the following investigations provides the most accurate prognostic information with respect to predicting risks of perioperative cardiac complications?
questions.solution:
Among the given investigations, dobutamine stress echocardiography provides the most accurate prognostic information with respect to predicting risks of perioperative cardiac complications.

Preoperative cardiac stress testing can help identify the presence and severity of preexisting CAD. The prognostic performance of these tests is better assessed based on positive and negative likelihood ratios. Among all the given options, dobutamine stress echocardiography has the maximum positive likelihood ratio and hence provides the most accurate prognostic information.

Even though coronary angiography is considered the gold standard, it may not absolutely risk-stratify patients because many perioperative cardiac events may be related to noncritical coronary lesions.

questions.text: A critically ill patient was given an infusion of an intravenous anesthetic at a dose of 4mg/kg/hour. 48 hours later, the patient developed refractory bradycardia, and there was evidence of rhabdomyolysis on investigations. Which agent is most likely implicated?
questions.solution:
The given features point towards a diagnosis of propofol infusion syndrome. It is a rare but lethal syndrome seen when the dose of propofol infusion is > 4 mg/kg/hour for 48 hours or longer.

This syndrome is common in children and critically ill adults.

Clinical features:

  • Acute refractory bradycardia leading to asystole in the presence of one or more of the following:
    • Metabolic acidosis (base deficit >10 mmol/L)
    • Rhabdomyolysis
    • Hyperlipidemia
    • Enlarged or fatty liver
  • Other features -  cardiomyopathy with acute cardiac failure, skeletal myopathy, hyperkalemia, hepatomegaly, and lipemia.

The symptoms and signs are the results of muscle injury and the release of intracellular toxic contents. It is due to defect in mitochondrial metabolism and electron transport chain function.

questions.text: You are an anesthetist who needs to administer general anesthesia to an obese patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Preoperatively, you assess the airway using the modified Mallampati classification and conclude that the patient falls under class III. How does her airway probably look?
questions.solution:
The patient’s airway was classified as Mallampati class III, so it probably looks like image 3. Here, the soft palate and base of the uvula are seen.

The Modified Mallampati classification is used to predict difficulty in tracheal intubation. It is based on the size of the base of the tongue. During the assessment, the patient has to be seated, with the head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruding, and no phonation. In this position, the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate is assessed and assigned a class from I-IV. 

The initial Mallampati classification included only classes I-III. It was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class IV. 

In addition to class I-IV, a fifth class also exists called class 0. In this, the epiglottis can be seen when the mouth is opened and tongue is protruded. However, it is still not proven by studies whether class 0 is a sign of easy intubation or not. 

Other options:

Option A: In Mallampati class IV, the soft palate is not visible at all.

Option B: In Mallampati class I, the soft palate, fauces, uvula, and tonsillar pillars are visible.

Option D: In Mallampati class II, the soft palate, fauces, and portion of uvula are visible.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: Identify the laryngoscopic blade given in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given image is that of the Macintosh laryngoscopic blade, an instrument that allows for laryngeal examination and tracheal intubation. It is the most commonly used laryngoscopic blade for endotracheal intubation in adults.

Laryngoscopic blades can be:

  • Curved  - Macintosh
  • Straight - Miller

Miller is the most commonly used blade in infants.

Advantage of curved blade:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

The tip of the curved Macintosh blade is placed in the vallecula after the tongue is slid leftward and anteriorly. The laryngoscope handle is lifted in a forward and upward direction (stretching the hyoepiglottic ligament). This causes the epiglottis to move upward, eventually exposing the vocal cords.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient admitted to the intensive medical care unit with suspected meningoencephalitis is undergoing the procedure shown below. All the following structures are pierced during this procedure, except ________.
questions.solution:
The patient is undergoing a procedure of lumbar puncture as shown in the image. All the given structures are pierced during lumbar puncture, except the posterior longitudinal ligament.

Lumbar puncture is a diagnostic procedure done to obtain a sample of cerebrospinal fluid from the subarachnoid space. The following structures are pierced during lumbar puncture, in that order:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Epidural space
  • Dura
  • Arachnoid
  • Subarachnoid space 

Indications:

  • Diagnosis of suspected meningitis and subarachnoid hemorrhage 
  • Spinal anesthesia and intrathecal administration of antibiotics/ chemotherapy
  • Therapeutic relief of pseudomotor cerebri, less frequently

Contraindications for lumbar puncture include:

  • Absolute- Infection over the site 
  • Relative-
    • Coagulopathy
    • Raised intracranial pressure
    • Spinal epidural abscess

Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is a common post-procedure symptom. It occurs due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. The headache in PDPH is typically frontal or occipital. It is aggravated with the upright or sitting posture and is relieved by lying supine. 

Other complications include infections, bleeding, cerebral herniation, and radicular pain.

questions.text: Glycopyrrolate is used as a pre-anesthetic agent for:
questions.solution:
Glycopyrrolate is used as a pre-anesthetic agent for reducing the secretions.

Anticholinergic drugs e.g. atropine, glycopyrrolate are routinely administered with anticholinesterases in order to attenuate the undesirable muscarinic effects. Glycopyrrolate is usually preferred because it has less vagolytic effects than atropine at doses that inhibit secretions and does not cross the blood-brain barrier. It should be administered as early as possible to maximize its effectiveness.

Glycopyrrolate 0.2 mg IV, is administered to dry airway secretions before flexible scope intubation of the trachea, during the bronchoscopic examination.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding transient neurological symptoms associated with spinal anesthesia?

choices.text: Presents as buttock pain radiating to legs
Reduced incidence  with the use of double-orifice needles

questions.solution:
Transient neurological symptoms (TNS) are less common with bupivacaine and other local anesthetics.

TNS was previously known as transient radicular irritation. It is mostly attributed to the use of intrathecal lidocaine and mepivacaine. It is most common in patients who were placed in lithotomy position during surgery.

Symptoms occur within 48 hours of resolution of spinal anesthetic. It presents as unilateral or bilateral pain in the buttocks that radiates to the legs. 

It is not related to the concentration of lidocaine, the addition of dextrose or epinephrine or solution osmolarity. Its incidence is decreased by the use of double-orifice needle, since single-orifice needles can increase the risk of injecting the anesthetic caudally in the thecal sac.

This condition is usually self-limiting. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs can be given. Some patients may require opioids.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient is posted for TURP  (transurethral resection of prostate) under subarachnoid block. Up to which dermatome must the anesthetist ensure adequate anesthesia?
questions.solution:
For procedures like TURP, the sensory block should be achieved up to T10 dermatomal level, as the pain-sensitive peritoneum innervation starts from T10 level.

Dermatomal level of required sensory blocks for various common surgical procedures:

  • T10 - Transurethral resection of the prostate, Hip surgery

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant woman in the active stage of labor requests epidural anesthesia. Immediately following the injection of 1.5% lidocaine with 1:200,000 epinephrine through the epidural catheter, the patient complains of lip numbness and becomes very apprehensive. Her heart rate is 110/min and her BP is 90/60 mmHg.  What is this most likely due to?
questions.solution:
The above condition is most likely due to accidental intravascular injection of local anaesthetic into the epidural vein resulting in local anaesthesia systemic toxicity (LAST).

Features of LAST:

  1. CNS (in the order of appearance)
    • Tinnitus, blurred vision, dizziness, tongue paresthesia, and circumoral numbness
    • Excitatory signs such as nervousness, agitation, restlessness, and muscle twitching leading to tonic-clonic seizures
    • CNS depression with slurred speech, drowsiness, unconsciousness, and then respiratory arrest
    • Patients who have received CNS depressant drugs may present with only CNS depression without any preceding excitatory signs
  2. CVS
    • Prolonged PR intervals and widened QRS complexes, and sinus bradycardia/arrest
    • Ventricular arrhythmias, including fibrillation, are more likely to occur with bupivacaine than lidocaine.

Prevention:

  • Careful aspiration for CSF (to rule out intrathecal placement) and blood (to rule out intravascular placement) before injecting the local anaesthesia
  • Use of a test dose with lidocaine and adrenaline
  • Incremental injection techniques instead of a bolus dose
  • Close observation for early signs of intravascular injection

Treatment:

  • Supplemental oxygen should be given.
  • Seizures: Benzodiazepine; if not available, a small dose of propofol or thiopentone. If seizures persist, a neuromuscular blockade to minimize acidosis and hypoxemia
  • Cardiac arrest: standard ACLS protocol with few modifications
  • Lipid emulsion therapy
  • Last resort: cardio-pulmonary bypass

questions.text:
You are doing your first-year residency in anesthesia. In which of the following patients would you administer a higher amount of inhalational anesthetic?
  1. A 5-month-old child undergoing surgery.
  2. A 22-year-old man with serum sodium levels 150 mmol/L.
  3. A 50-year-old woman with BP 80/55 mmHg.
  4. A 16-year-old girl with hemoglobin< 6gm/dL.
  5. A 30-year-old woman with serum calcium levels 7 mg/dL.
questions.solution:
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) increases in neonates, hypernatremia (total serum sodium >145 mmol/L), and hypocalcemia (total serum calcium < 8.8 mg/dL). Thus, 1, 2, and 5 will require a higher amount of inhalational anesthetic agents.

MAC is defined as the inhaled anesthetic atmospheric pressure required to prevent movement in response to a defined noxious stimulus in 50% of subjects. MAC is unique to each inhaled anesthetic. 

It is used to express the potency of anesthetic agents. Thus, the lower the MAC, the higher the potency. 

Hypotensive patients (blood pressure < 90/60 mmHg) and patients with anemia would require a lower amount of anesthetic agents.

Effect of age on MAC: MAC is the highest at 6 months of age, after which it declines. After the age of 40, MAC reduces by ~6% per decade.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is posted for surgery under general anesthesia. Which of the following inhalational agent cannot be used for induction of anesthesia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Desflurane cannot be used for the induction of anesthesia in this patient since it produces laryngospasm when used for inhalational anesthesia. Laryngospasm is because of the pungent nature of the gas. The incidence of laryngospasm following desflurane induction is almost 50%.

Desflurane has a rapid onset of action and also rapid emergence from anesthesia. Therefore, it is of particular value in neurosurgical and spinal fusion procedures where rapid awakening is required for neurological function assessment. It is also used for the maintenance of anesthesia.  Desflurane has no hepatic metabolism.

Other options:

Option A: Halothane is the preferred drug for gaseous induction of anesthesia in children. However, the incidence of halothane hepatitis and myocardial depression has reduced its use in children.

Option B: Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational agent for induction in the pediatric age group. Cardiovascular depression, bradycardia, and arrhythmias are less frequent with sevoflurane than with halothane and hence the former is preferred.

Option D: Nitrous oxide is the least potent as it has the highest minimum alveolar concentration. It is combined with other potent inhaled anesthetics to reduce their dose. It can be used to hasten the induction of anesthesia along with other induction agents.

questions.text: A female patient underwent surgery under general anesthesia 2 days ago. On the first postoperative day, her liver enzymes were elevated, and she developed jaundice. It was diagnosed that she developed hepatitis due to halothane, which was used during surgery. What type of hepatic damage is usually seen in this type of halothane hepatitis?
questions.solution:
The most common type of hepatic damage that occurs in halothane hepatitis is centrilobular necrosis.

Halothane is commonly known to be associated with complications such as hepatotoxicity and massive hepatic necrosis. Other volatile anesthetics, including enflurane, isoflurane, and desflurane, have also been associated with fulminant hepatic necrosis, but compared with toxicity due to halothane, potentially fatal toxicity from the administration of these newer volatile anesthetics is rare.

Clinical types: Clinical exposure to halothane is associated with two distinct types of hepatic injury:

  • Subclinical hepatotoxicity: It is characterized by mild postoperative elevations in alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase, but is reversible and innocuous.
  • Halothane hepatitis: It is a fulminant form of hepatotoxicity, characterized by elevated alanine aminotransferase, aspartate aminotransferase, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels, and massive hepatic necrosis following the administration of halothane.

Mechanism of injury:

Halothane-induced hepatitis is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction associated with the oxidative metabolism of halothane. This causes the release of a highly reactive trifluoroacetyl (TFA) chloride metabolite that cross-reacts with nearby liver proteins resulting in the formation of TFA-modified proteins. The TFA-modified proteins serve as neoantigens and the antibodies against them are attributed to liver injury.

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident had difficulty in breathing and multiple bone fractures. Chest X-Ray revealed a pneumothorax and an emergency needle thoracostomy is performed. The patient was shifted to the operation theatre for management of the fractures. Which of the following inhalational agents would you avoid in this patient?
questions.solution:
The inhalational agent to be avoided in a patient with pneumothorax undergoing surgery is nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide has greater diffusibility across tissue than nitrogen. It has the potential to expand air-containing cavities, specifically nitrogen-containing spaces, and replace nitrogen. Hence, it should be avoided in patients with pneumothorax. 

Due to its greater diffusibility, nitrous oxide is avoided in 

  • arterial air embolism
  • pneumothorax
  • acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distension
  • intracranial air
  • pulmonary air cysts
  • intraocular air bubbles
  • tympanic membrane grafting
  • middle ear surgeries

Nitrous oxide can even diffuse into tracheal tube cuffs, increasing its pressure and hampering mucosal blood circulation. 

The other options are not specifically contraindicated in pneumothorax as they do not worsen the condition. Their effects on the respiratory system are given below:

Option A: Desflurane causes a decrease in tidal volume and an increase in respiratory rate. Due to its pungent nature, it causes airway irritation leading to increased salivation, coughing, and laryngospasm.

Option B: Halothane causes rapid and shallow breathing as it stimulates ventilatory efforts. It is a potent bronchodilator but depresses the clearance of mucus from the respiratory tract. 

Option C: Sevoflurane depresses respiration and reverses bronchospasm similar to isoflurane. 

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.solution:
The correctly matched muscle relaxants with their respective durations of action are 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B.

Neuromuscular blocking drugs (NMBDs) are administered to facilitate endotracheal intubation, mechanical ventilation, and various surgical procedures by relaxing skeletal muscles. However, they are not administered to prevent patient movement. There are two types of NMBDs:

  • Depolarizing: Succinylcholine is the only available depolarizing NMBD, characterized by rapid onset and ultrashort duration of action.
  • Non-depolarizing:
    • Many NMBDs are available, classified according to chemical class or duration of action.
    • They produce neuromuscular blockade by competing with acetylcholine for the postsynaptic α subunits.
    • The speed of onset is inversely proportional to the potency of the drug.
    • The normal neuromuscular function must return after the administration of the drug, using objective means of monitoring. Residual neuromuscular paralysis decreases esophageal tone and disrupts muscle coordination during swallowing.

questions.text: In the medical ward, SpO2 of a 14-year-old female patient was found to be 85% despite 100% oxygenation. She is hemodynamically stable. On examination, she has nail polish over her fingernails. Which of the following color of nail polish is associated with inaccurate/ falsely low readings in pulse oximeter?
questions.solution:
Purple color nail polish gives inaccurate/falsely low readings in pulse-oximeter. Nail polish colors which give inaccurate readings in pulse-oximeter are, purple, dark blue and black.

Pulse oximetry is a non-invasive measurement of the oxygen saturation of hemoglobin. 

But, a pulse oximeter is not always reliable as it reads

  • Falsely high - carboxyhemoglobinemia 
  • Falsely low - severe anemia, low cardiac output states, hypovolemia, increased systemic vascular resistance 
  • 80% to 85%, irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation - methemoglobinemia

questions.text: A 15-month-old child who is posted for a minor surgical procedure is brought by his mother for preoperative evaluation. What would be the recommended period of fasting for this child?

choices.text: 6 hours for light meal, 2 hours for clear fluids
6 hours for fried foods, 2 hours for clear fluids
6  hours for light meal, 4 hours for clear fluids
6 hours for fried foods, 4 hours for clear fluids

questions.solution:
The recommended preoperative fasting period for this child is 6 hours for a light meal and 2 hours for clear fluids.

Recommended preoperative fasting periods for all above 1 year of age are 2 hours for clear fluids, 6 hours for a light meal, and 8 hours for fried, fatty food.

Recommended preoperative fasting periods for neonates and infants are 6 hours for solids/ formula feeds/ cow's milk, and 4 hours for breast milk.

The goal of recommending preoperative fasting periods is to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: The opioid which has maximum lipid solubility is ________
questions.solution:
Sufentanil has the highest water partition coefficient and hence has the maximum lipid solubility.

Therefore, Sufentanil is the most potent opioid.

Opioids wih a high octanol/water partition coefficient are called lipophilic opioids. They have a rapid onset and a much shorter duration of action. It is ideal for continuous epidural infusion (CEI) or patient controlled epidural anesthesia (PCEA).

Fentanyl is 100 times more potent and sufentanil is 1000 times more potent than morphine.

questions.text: A patient is posted for an elective procedure under general anesthesia. Being an intern in the anesthetist's team, you are asked to monitor the bispectral Index. What will be the bispectral index (BIS) reading if the patient is still in a state of sedation and not under adequate general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
The range of bispectral index reading if the patient is still in the state of sedation and not under adequate general anesthesia is 65-85.

It processes the EEG and provides an index value between 0 and 100 that indicates the patient’s level of consciousness. BIS monitors examine four components within the EEG that are associated with the anesthetic state.

  1. Low frequency, as found during deep anesthesia.
  2. High-frequency beta activation, found during light anesthesia.
  3. Suppressed EEG waves.
  4. Burst suppression.

It has numerical values from 0 to 100, with 0 representing isoelectric EEG and 100 being awake CNS. Recommended range of Bispectral index (BIS) for general anesthesia is 40-65.

     65-85 sedation

Monitors used to assess the depth of anesthesia are:

questions.text: What alternative drug would you use for cardiac arrest if epinephrine is not effective?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine and amiodarone are the two main drugs approved by the AHA for the resuscitation of a cardiac arrest patient.

questions.text:
A male patient was given anesthesia for a surgical procedure. After a few minutes, the anesthetist noticed there was a masseter muscle spasm in the patient. His vitals are given below. Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause this condition?
  • Pulse rate - 134/min
  • Blood pressure - 150/90 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate - 28/min
  • Temperature - 102ºF
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of masseter muscle spasm with hyperthermia and elevated blood pressure suggests the diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia. The least likely drug to cause this condition is atracurium.

Malignant hyperthermia is a hypermetabolic condition, seen on exposure to inhaled anesthetics or succinylcholine. 

The pathophysiology behind the development of malignant hyperthermia is that there is an uncontrolled increase in intracellular calcium in skeletal muscle. This sudden release of calcium can result in sustained muscle contraction by removing the inhibition of troponin. This leads to increased oxygen consumption, and increased CO2 production, producing severe lactic acidosis and hyperthermia. 

Drugs known to trigger this condition include: 

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, ether, methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine.

Atracurium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant and is not implicated in malignant hyperthermia.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

CPR - Cardio-pulmonary resuscitation

questions.text: Identify the following circuit shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The given circuit is Bain's circuit which is a coaxial modification of the Mapleson D circuit since it has two tubings- inner and outer tubing.

Bain's circuit has
  • Inner inspiratory tubing: carries fresh gas flow to the patient
  • Outer expiratory tubing: carries exhaled gases out through APL (adjustable pressure limiting) valve

The fresh gas tube enters the outer corrugated tube near the reservoir bag, but it actually enters the circuit near the patient. The exhaled gases pass through the outer corrugated tube and get vented out via the pop-off valve near the reservoir bag. These exhaled gases that pass through the outer corrugated tube provide warmth to the inspired fresh gases by countercurrent heat exchange.

The main hazards related to the use of the Bain’s circuit are an unrecognized disconnection or kinking of the inner fresh gas hose. These problems can cause hypercapnia as a result of inadequate gas flow or increased respiratory resistance. The outer corrugated tube must be transparent to allow ongoing inspection of the inner tube.

Option B - Magill's circuit is also known as Mapelson A circuit. It has a spring-loaded pop-off valve near the facemask. Gas enters the circuit opposite the side of the patient. It is best for allowing spontaneous breathing but worst for controlled ventilation. 

Option C - Jackson Rees circuit is also known as the Mapelson F circuit. It is similar to the Mapleson D circuit. It has a hole at the distal end of the reservoir bag that can be occluded to control distension and pressure. It is used during patient transport and preoxygenation.

questions.text: In which of the following patients would you prefer not to use a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) for securing the airway?

choices.text: Providing CPR to a patient who had a road traffic accident
A 45-year-old male patient with suspected lung carcinoma, planned for bronchoscopy
A 50-year-old man planned for laparoscopic appendicectomy, having Mallampati class III airway
A term G2P1L1 previously diagnosed with preeclampsia planned for elective LSCS

questions.solution:
From the above-given options, laryngeal mask airway (LMA) cannot be used in a term woman previously diagnosed with preeclampsia planned for elective LSCS. This is because pregnancy is a state which is more prone to aspiration and hence LMA is contraindicated.

A laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic device that consists of a wide bore tube. It has a proximal end connected to a breathing circuit while a distal end is connected to an elliptical cuff which can be inflated through a pilot tube. 

It is inserted in a deflated manner following lubrication blindly into the hypopharynx. After inflation, it forms a low-pressure seal around the laryngeal entry. Ideally positioned cuff will have the base of the tongue superiorly and the upper esophageal sphincter inferiorly. Pyriform sinuses should be present laterally.

It is indicated in cases with difficult airways where endotracheal intubation is not possible or not available. It can be used as an alternative to an endotracheal tube for ventilating and oxygenating the patient.  

Indications are acute trauma, difficult intubation, and laparoscopic surgeries, to facilitate fibreoptic intubation.

LMA is relatively contraindicated in

  • Conditions that are associated with an increased risk of aspiration such as hiatus hernia, and pregnancy. 
  • The presence of a pharyngeal pathology such as an abscess or tumor, or a pharyngeal obstruction.
  • Low pulmonary compliance.

Advantages of LMA are hands-free operation, better seal, and easy-to-maintain airway. It protects against secretions when compared to face masks. When compared with tracheal intubation, it is less invasive, useful in difficult intubations, causes less damage to the tooth and larynx, and does not require muscle relaxant and mobilization of the neck.

The disadvantages associated with the use of LMA in comparison with tracheal intubation are increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration, less safe in prone or jack-knife positions, less secure airway, and greater risk of a gas leak and pollution.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about eutectic mixture of local anesthetic (EMLA)?
  1. It is a eutectic mixture containing 1% lidocaine and 1% prilocaine 
  2. EMLA is unsafe in all neonates due to methemoglobinemia 
  3. Can be used in circumcision, laser treatments and skin grafting 
  4. Longer application of the cutaneous adhesive bandage increases the depth of analgesia 
  5. It must be applied under an occlusive bandage for a minimum of 15 mins for the anesthetic action
questions.solution:
Statements 3 and 4 are true about EMLA. 

EMLA (Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetic) cream consists of a 1:1 mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine.

An eutectic mixture has a melting point lesser than the individual drugs and hence the mixture is in the oil form at room temperature.

EMLA can provide adequate dermal analgesia for procedures like:

  • Split skin-graft harvesting
  • Venipuncture
  • Intravenous cannulation in children
  • Laser skin treatments
  • Lithotripsy
  • Circumcision

EMLA cream should not be used on mucous membranes, broken skin, infants younger than 1 month of age, or patients with a predisposition to methemoglobinemia.

Side Effects include- blanching of the skin, erythema, and edema.  

EMLA is applied 45-60 minutes before the procedure with an occlusive dressing as shown in the above image. It provides analgesia up to a depth of 5 mm which lasts for 1-2 hours.

Methemoglobinemia occurs with large doses of prilocaine, upwards of 600mg. EMLA is a topical mixture containing prilocaine, and in term neonates, minimal amounts of methemoglobin are produced, which can be safely excreted. Thus it is regarded as safe in the majority of newborns.
The risk is increased in neonates with metabolic disorders or in those receiving drugs that can impair the reduction of methemoglobin.
For this, as evidence suggests, EMLA is not unsafe in all neonates.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding the combined spinal-epidural needle?

choices.text: It has slower onset of action
It  does not allow for increasing of block height
It is used commonly in obstetric anesthesia
It is not used for immediate pain relief

questions.solution:
The combined spinal-epidural (CSE) anesthesia is most widely used in obstetric anesthesia in labor. 

Combined spinal-epidural allows for clinical flexibility, with a rapid onset of action from the spinal block and a longer duration of analgesia and anesthesia with the epidural catheter. The epidural catheter can be left in situ to manage post-operative pain.  

When CSE is used during labor, an opioid and a local anesthetic are introduced via the spinal route for immediate pain relief. The epidural catheter is used for continued pain relief and operative intervention (if required). 

It has the advantage of dose flexibility, as the target block height can be reached by topping up the drug via the epidural catheter when required. This allows a lower dose of spinal anesthetic to be given initially.

Additional use is in increasing block height. This can be done by additional infiltration of a local anesthetic or saline to the epidural space via the catheter in a patient on the spinal block. This will compress the dural sac and increase the block height. This is called epidural volume extension (EVE) and has been shown to provide significantly faster recovery in cesarean section patients.

This method has many benefits such as 

  • Reduced side effects
  • Faster recovery
  • Earlier discharge 
  • Better hemodynamic stability for high-risk patients

A brachial plexus block is given by injecting a local anesthetic at the point shown in the image. Which of the following nerves are blocked in this procedure?
  1. Ulnar nerve
  2. Median nerve
  3. Musculocutaneous nerve
  4. Radial nerve
questions.solution:
The image shows a local anesthetic being injected into the tip of the axilla around the axillary artery. This is the method used to perform the axillary block. The nerves blocked are the ulnar, radial, and median nerves. 

The axillary block is used for elbow and distal upper extremity anesthesia. The most important landmark is the pulse of the axillary artery just distal to the pectoralis major near the anterior axillary wall. Usually, the median, ulnar, and radial nerves (close the arterial wall) and the musculocutaneous nerve (showing a characteristic medial-to-lateral course in the axilla) can be seen.

Although this is a safe and effective technique, the musculocutaneous nerve fails to be blocked as it changes its course from adjacent the axillary artery to within the coracobrachialis muscle and then exiting the muscle. However, this can be prevented by ultrasound imaging, which helps in direct visualization of the nerve. 

The arm to be blocked should be abducted at 90° and the forearm may be supported horizontally at 90° or above or behind the head for optimal positioning of the patient for the procedure.

questions.text: You are assisting your senior resident who is performing the procedure shown in the image. He engages you with some historical trivia and asks you who performed this procedure first. What would your answer be?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the above picture is spinal anesthesia.

The first case of spinal anesthesia in humans was performed by August Bier in 1898. He performed spinal anesthesia using the local anesthetic cocaine.

Spinal anesthesia involves the administration of a local anesthetic into the spinal subarachnoid space to provide motor and sensory blockade. Another contribution by August Bier is 'Bier's block' or IVRA (intravenous regional anesthesia).

questions.text: Which of the following local anaesthetics is not metabolised by plasma esterase?
questions.solution:
Cocaine is the only amino ester that is not metabolized by plasma cholinesterases. It is partially metabolized by hepatic carboxylesterase and partially excreted unchanged in the urine.

Articaine is the only amino amide which is inactivated by plasma esterases.

Note: Cocaine is a vasoconstrictor due to its property of norepinephrine reuptake inhibition. All the other local anaesthetics are vasodilators except cocaine.

questions.text: During a coronary artery bypass graft surgery, the surgeon uses a therapeutic gas to flood the surgical field. Which of the following would he use?
questions.solution:
Carbon dioxide (CO2) is commonly used to flood the surgical field during cardiac surgery. 

A common cause of myocardial ischemia during open-heart surgery is air embolism to the coronary arteries.

Carbon dioxide because of its higher density, displaces the air surrounding the open heart so that any gas bubbles trapped in the heart are of carbon dioxide (soluble) and not nitrogen (insoluble).

questions.text: An anesthetist used the airway device shown in the image given below on a patient. Which among the following statements is true regarding the adjunct?

choices.text: It can cause damage to the teeth
It can be used in conscious patients
It can be safely used in facial trauma cases

questions.solution:
The image shows a nasopharyngeal airway and its insertion. The true statement is that it can be used in conscious patients. 

A nasopharyngeal airway is used to provide artificial airway passage to the hypopharynx. To place a nasopharyngeal airway, the device should be lubricated and inserted into the nose with the bevel facing the nasal septum, at a 90-degree angle to the longitudinal axis of the body. It bypasses the gag reflex as they do not go through the mouth. Thus, it can be used in conscious patients or those who have been lightly anesthetized.

Care should be taken to avoid excessive force as damage to the nasal mucosa can result in epistaxis. The nasal approach should be avoided in conditions that put patients at higher risk for epistaxis. These conditions include but are not limited to coagulopathy, pregnancy, hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, and uncontrolled hypertension. Absolute contraindications include basilar skull fractures, facial trauma, midface disruption, and injury to the roof of the mouth.

An oropharyngeal airway is used to maintain the airway in anaesthetized patients. This adjunct prevents the tongue and epiglottis from falling back against the posterior pharynx and blocking the airway. They can cause coughing, retching, or laryngospasm in conscious patients.

To place an oropharyngeal airway, the device is inserted with the curved portion (concave) facing upwards. It is then rotated 180 degrees to be put in place. The below image shows the oropharyngeal airway:

Other options: 

Option A: Nasopharyngeal airways bypass the mouth so they do not cause damage to the teeth. Oropharyngeal airways can cause damage to the teeth. 

Option C: Nasopharyngeal airways can cause laryngospasm. Any foreign body that enters the nasal or oral cavities can cause local stimulation leading to reflex closure of the vocal cords. 

Option D: Its usage is contraindicated in facial trauma.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient was brought to the trauma center following a bike accident. He was stuporous, speaking incoherent words in response to painful stimuli and bleeding from a deep penetrating wound in his right thigh. On examination, his pulse was weak and 110/min. His BP was 90/66 mmHg. His respiration rate was 22/min. The skin on his extremities was cold and clammy. What is the best method of restoring adequate cardiac output and tissue oxygenation in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture points towards a diagnosis of hemorrhagic shock.

Nearly 70% of the body’s total blood volume is estimated to be located in the venous circuit. Compliance of the venous system involves a relationship between venous volume and venous pressure. This pressure gradient drives venous flow and therefore the volume of venous return to the heart. Blood loss depletes this component of venous volume and reduces the pressure gradient; consequently, venous return is reduced.

In a case of hemorrhagic shock, the most effective method of restoring adequate cardiac output, end-organ perfusion, and tissue oxygenation is to restore venous return to normal by locating and stopping the source of bleeding.

Other options:

  • Volume repletion will allow recovery from the shock state only when the bleeding has stopped and the first line is crystalloids, not blood products.
  • Since the patient already has cutaneous vasoconstriction, vasopressors are not administered without prior adequate fluid resuscitation to avoid further vasoconstriction and gangrene formation.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the anesthesia department. While intubating a patient, you notice the following type of waveform in capnogram. This capnogram is usually seen in patients with _____.
questions.solution:
The image given is a capnogram seen in patients with esophageal intubation. SpO2 may be normal for 1 or 2 minutes, but then suddenly falls. The waveform that occurs in capnogram is due to the CO2 in the stomach from the swallowed expired air, which gets washed out in a few breaths.

A capnogram is a graphical representation of the partial pressure of CO2 during respiration. It provides information about ventilation, perfusion, and metabolism in an individual.

It is commonly used to confirm endotracheal tube placement. The presence of a normal waveform for at least three breaths is confirmatory. 

The simplest and most widely used form of display for exhaled CO2 is the time capnogram. The time capnogram displays both inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components.

  • Phase 1: Represents the end of inspiration and the beginning of expiration, when the free CO2 gas that occupied the dead space in the airway is exhaled.
  • Phase 2: It represents a rapid rise in PCO2 as alveolar gas appears. 
  • Phase 3: This is a plateau phase where expiration continues but PCO2 doesn't rise any further. The end of this phase is taken as end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2).
  • Phase 4: There is a sharp drop in PCO2 to zero, representing inspiration.

Uses of capnogram:

  1. Surest confirmatory sign of correct intubation.
  2. Diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia.
  3. Detecting obstruction of endotracheal tube.
  4. Indicates cardiac output.
  5. Diagnosis of pulmonary embolism, etc.

questions.text: A 71-year-old patient underwent hip replacement surgery. Postoperatively, a target control infusion (TCI) pump was set up to administer an opioid analgesic. Which is the most suitable opioid used for this patient?
questions.solution:
Remifentanil is the opioid that was most likely used in this elderly patient.

Remifentanil is hydrolysed by plasma and tissue esterases and so its metabolism is independent of hepatic and renal function- no dose adjustment is required and is safe in liver failure patients and renal failure patients.

Because of this hydrolysis, it has a high clearance and is eliminated rapidly with a quick recovery ( half-life less than 10 minutes) and thus is preferred in elderly patients.
